text:
It’s the holidays folks, and that means
it’s time for some good old fashioned gluttony
and sloth.

But while you cuddle up by the fireplace with
some eggnog and a pile of cookies, we’re

going to give you some food for thought that
might help with your upcoming new year’s
resolution (Show gym).

Time to lose that dorky sweater -- the cold
may help kick start your 2017 weight loss.

Now, as for that New Year’s resolution,
let’s take a look at body fat.
Did you know that there are two types of fat?
Fatty tissue is made of cells called adipocytes.

When talking weight, people are referring
to “white fat” or white adipose tissue.

This fatty tissue is in the business of storing
energy and saving it for later.

It also happen to act as a sort of cushion
for your body – but too much is no good.

We’ll get back to white fat cells later,
for now, let’s focus on their colleagues,
the brown ones.

Brown fat is made up of adipose cells that
are fundamentally different from white fat

cells because they generate heat and burn
calories when stimulated.
That’s right, fat that burns calories!

This is in part due to their abundance of
mitochondria which produce everybody’s favorite
molecule of energy, ATP.

It just so happens that these mitochondria
also pack a ton of iron -- which is what gives
brown fat its rusty color.

Infants carry brown fat to help regulate their
body temperature because they don’t have
the ability to shiver.

Until recently It was thought that only babies
carried these types of fat cells, but now

research has shown that they do in fact exist
in adults, and you may be able to guess why…Exercise.

When you work out, the contraction of your
muscles produces a hormone called irisin.

This molecule eventually travels from your
bloodstream to fatty tissues, where it works
its it’s biochemical magic.

It can turn white fat cells into our prized
brown ones.

Original findings on irisin were based on
studies in mice, and some researchers began
questioning its prevalence in humans.

But more recent research shows that irisin
levels, while dormant in some adults, are
in fact increased by exercise.

Now, it has been known that non-shivering
cold can stimulate the production of brown

cells in the body on its own, but here’s
the kicker – ditching that dorky sweater

of yours can double down on the brown cell
production by jump-starting your body with
irisin.

Shivers occur when your brain takes in the
right information from your skin that it’s

cold defenses are running low, and it’s
time to start manually generating muscle heat.

Just like when you exercise, shivers are rapid
contractions of muscles, which stimulate irisin
production.

Brown fat cells start burning off and create
heat with or without shivers.

But with the addition of the freezing cold,
your shaking and shivering body can produce

a healthy dose of irisin, which makes your
white cells behave just like calorie-burning
brown ones.

And look, don’t get us wrong folks, being
cold obviously isn’t a healthier lifestyle

choice than hitting the gym because there’s
more benefits to exercise than just cutting
calories.

But it may shock you to learn that a recent
study showed that fifteen minutes in the freezing

cold can burn as many calories as one hour
of exercise.

So these crazy folks have the right idea (show
polar bear swim).

So this year, while you sit by the fire with
your ugly sweater, eggnog, and cookies, you
might want to reconsider – the colds waiting.

Post your holiday guilty pleasures in the
comments folks.

Thanks for watching, we hope you have a brilliant
holiday season.
Thumbs up and subscribe on the way out!
